data.title: Test: node2 - General bugbash
data.body:
- [x] any OS @weinand 
- [x] any OS @sandy081 

Effort: 3

There are a ton of little things that changed in the past month and it will be very helpful to do another general pass. Just spend a little time with it doing anything. At this point, basically anything that works in node-debug should also work in node-debug2.

From the previous testplan-item - 

> There are a million scenarios we need to support, so the most valuable thing you can do is grab any random Node project that you might have debugged with VS Code in the past, change "type" to "node2", and see what happens. If anything happens that isn't the same as "node", is it obvious to figure out what's wrong?
> 
> More specific things to try, don't need to do every single one:
> 
> Try some things that are checked off at Microsoft/vscode-node-debug2#7
> Ensure it kills the process when terminating a launch config, but not an attach
> Set breakpoints before launching, and ensure they bind
> In the main script, and in scripts that are loaded later
> Look in the variables pane at different types and compare it to what you'd expect
> Test very large arrays and other stress cases
> It might get slow but it shouldn't crash
> Test with and without sourcemaps
> Attach config with a running process (start with --inspect=9229)

data.title: Test: node2 - debug console completions
data.body:
- [x] any OS @sandy081 
- [x] any OS @isidorn 

Effort: 2

Should work the same as node-debug, although I can't find the original testplan-item.

Test that it works at least at a breakpoint, not at a breakpoint, on globals, on properties in the local scope, and on properties in variables. It falls apart quickly with complex expressions, and there are a couple bugs filed already. Right now I'm mainly worried about bugs that node-debug doesn't also have.

data.title: Test: node2 - smartStep
data.body:
- [x] any OS @rebornix 
- [x] macOS @joaomoreno 

Effort: 2

Original test item for node-debug, it should work exactly the same using "node2": #4954.

Copied for your convenience:

> for #4798:
> 
> We added experimental support for automatically skipping 'uninteresting code' when stepping through code in the debugger. 'Uninteresting code' is code that is generated by a transpiling process but is not covered by a source map so it does not map back to the original source. Typically this code gets into your way when stepping through code in the debugger because it makes the debugger switch between the original source code and generated code that you are not really interested in.
> 
> This experimental feature automatically steps through code not covered by a source map until it has reached a location that is covered by a source map again. To enable the feature just add the attribute `smartStep` with a value of `true` to your launch configuration.
> 
> Here is a sample project: [async-sample.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/206813/async-sample.zip)
> - unzip and open in VS Code
> - npm install
> - npm run-script compile
> 
> Verify that:
> - stepping through code stays in the source and does not jump into the generated code (you can see the skipped steps in the debug console).
> - stepping still makes sense and you can follow what's going on

data.title: Support launching multiple launch configs manually?
data.body:
With the new "composite" launch config type, we can debug multiple processes simultaneously, but we have to launch them at the same time. This will be tricky any time you are launching 'client' and 'server'-like things, because the server may not be ready for a second, and the client may expect it to be ready immediately.

I tried to set this up with my node-debug2 tests, which was a scenario I'd had in mind, but it only works sometimes, depending on how quickly the debug adapter process starts up.

Have you talked about letting users start the server config, make sure it starts up correctly, then launch the client config once the server is ready?

2. type in any number of characters that match a file name
3. press left arrow to move to the left
4. press right arrow to move to the right

result: cursor does not move to the right.

data.title: Multi-target debugging - Can trigger commands with keyboard but not buttons, or vice-versa
data.body: Sometimes when debugging, keyboard shortcuts for debug actions stop working, but I can click the buttons in the debug palette to do actions. Or, the other way around. Often I try to kill the processes with 'shift+F5' and it works the first time, but I have to click the stop button to kill the second process.

data.title: Pause button shows up instead of Play while debugging multiple processes
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7-insiders
- OS Version: Windows

Testing #14171

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have the below configurations in `launch.json`

```
"configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Hello",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/hello/hello.js",
            "console": "internalConsole"
        },
        {
            "name": "Bye",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/bye/bye.js",          
            "console": "internalConsole"
        },
        {
            "name": "Multi",
            "type": "composite",
            "configurationNames": [
                "Hello",
                "Bye"
            ]
        }
    ]
```
1. Have breakpoints set in both `hello.js` and `bye.js`.
2. Launch the "Multi" configuration
3. Switch between the callstacks of the 2 processes, choose any and hit F5 or the Play button in the debug bar to continue
4. Select the remaining process in the callstack pane. 
5. At this point you would expect the Play button to appear, instead the Pause button appears. The Step Into/Over/Out buttons are disabled

data.title: Multi-target debugging - Breakpoints show as unbound, but execution still pauses there
data.body:
We saw this with the Go debugger and node2, but not node.

Set breakpoints in two files. Launch them with two separate configs and a 'composite' config. In one file, the breakpoint will show as unbound, but execution still pauses there, because it is actually bound.

This doesn't happen with every setup, but it happens pretty often, and I have one where it happens every time that I can send if needed. The logs show that the debug adapter reported the bp as verified.

Removes all animations/transitions from the watermark.  Everything is instantaneous and snappy (including when you close editors, open a new window, and when you resize).

data.title: Test: JavaScript intellisense is available without the need for configuration
data.body:
Test item for #14296.
- [x] any OS @bpasero
- [x] any OS @octref 

complexity: 4

The TypeScript language server in VS Code is used to provide intellisense within Javascript files. For VS Code 1.7, we switched to v2.0.6 of the TypeScript language server. v2.0.6 monitors the `package.json` files and installs for all dependencies the most recent, available typing files in a global cache on the file system. On macOs the cache is at `~/Library/Application Support/Microsoft/TypeScript/node_modules/@types`.

Test Scenarios:
1. Write a small node.js application from scratch in JavaScript.
2. Clone an existing node.js application written in JavaScript and modify it.

While editing the application's JS files you should get meaningful intellisense proposals for node and it's built-in modules as well as any module your application depends on.

Notes:
1. Before each of the tests, clear the cache location to make sure that a populated cache does not hide a situation in which the automated acquisition of typing files fails.
2. Test with autosave enabled and disabled.
3. Ensure that you also run `npm install` when you make changes to the `package.json` file. An increasing number of node modules includes the typings file directly.

data.title: Visible whitespace disappears when `editor.renderIndentGuides` is true

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: `Version 1.7.0-insider (1.7.0-insider)` c038219f8d137b4972a15346b81ea03751d669d4
- OS Version: `macOS Sierra 10.12 (16A323)`

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set `"editor.renderWhitespace": "boundary"` and `"editor.renderIndentGuides": true`
2. Open a TypeScript file (haven't tried others
3. Only the indent guides are visible

Although if you toggle those settings while the file is opened it will render properly.

data.title: Large minified JavaScript files cause VSCode to lockup and then crash

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open a very large minified JavaScript file in vscode, like that of wordpress.  More than 30,000 characters over about 400-500 lines.  Sometimes it doesn't lock up right away, but after a few minutes it does.  I have had instances where it kept locking up immediately after opening the file.  I have had to use notepad++ in order to edit these files.

Note: Trying to save this file doesn't work, no matter how many times I click save.

This is the dialog I am presented with after being in the file for a few minutes or trying to save.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7989333/19663708/26d5b73c-9a0b-11e6-85bd-5864146ff62d.png)

data.title: Contributions showing "unknown" for keybindings
data.body:
VS Code Insiders 1.7
macOS

I have created this [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.atom-keybindings). The contributions is a list of keybindings from Atom. 

The following keybindings are not resolving. In the contributions list it shows the keybinding as unknown. 

``` json
{
  "mac": "cmd+shift+{",
  "win": "ctrl+pagedown",
  "linux": "ctrl+pagedown",
  "key": "ctrl+pagedown",
  "command": "workbench.action.nextEditor"
},
{
  "mac": "cmd+shift+}",
  "win": "ctrl+pageup",
  "linux": "ctrl+pageup",
  "key": "ctrl+pageup",
  "command": "workbench.action.previousEditor"
},
{
  "mac": "cmd++",
  "win": "ctrl++",
  "linux": "ctrl++",
  "key": "ctrl++",
  "command": "workbench.action.zoomIn"
}
```

macOS:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19661094/25460f6c-99e7-11e6-9f3e-7243f939c4c1.png)

Windows:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19661396/67e67306-99e8-11e6-9706-ed2bb2fa586a.png)

My first thought was that the characters `{`, `}`, and `+` needed to be escaped. However, doing so causes an error. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19661253/de221760-99e7-11e6-974b-44ab5ffd6b25.png)

This is also happening with [Sublime Text Keymap](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) extension. 

Windows:

``` json
 {
  "mac": "alt+cmd+[",
  "key": "ctr+shift+[",
  "command": "editor.fold",
   "when": "editorFocus"
},
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19661572/19963b36-99e9-11e6-805c-c4fc10bdf27b.png)

``` json
{
  "mac": "cmd++",
  "key": "ctrl++",
  "command": "workbench.action.zoomIn"
}
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19661581/21338d1c-99e9-11e6-90ad-44170f354436.png)

``` json
{
  "mac": "alt+f12",
  "key": "context_menu",
  "command": "editor.action.showContextMenu",
  "when": "editorTextFocus"
},
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/19661620/42c1903c-99e9-11e6-86d7-353b1a38c47b.png)

data.title: tsconfig.json falsely processed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan 10.11.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install [Yeoman Office-Generator](https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/runtimes/office) and generate a project.
2. Run "tsd install" from project folder (alternatively use typings).
3. Test IntelliSense in VS Code by typing "Office." in "home.js" f.e.
4. Set allowJs in tsconfig.json to true => Now it should work.

allowJs in tsconfig.json should be true by default (according to [the doc](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/compiler-options.html)). So I guess it´s a bug that VS Code does not allowJS by default.

data.title: Add support for large text files
data.body:
Now when you open a file that is a bit large you get a message that the file is too large and can't be opened.

Would it be possible to still allow the file to be opened in a "stream mode"? Basically you can disable the syntax highlight (and maybe other features that would be resource intensive to implement on large files) but open and read the file in chunks of data (what's needed to be displayed on screen) and load more as you scroll (up or down)?

data.title: Integrated terminal unlimited buffer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.6.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run command in terminal that continuously spits output
2. Monitor memory usage with Activity Monitor

It seems as if, at least by default, vscode's integrated terminal has an unlimited buffer. Is this by design, or is there a way to limit this somehow?

data.title: Test: ESLint autofix on save
data.body:
Tests ESLint auto fix on save.
- [x] Any platform @rebornix 

Complexity - 2

vscode-eslint is now supporting autofix on save:
- The setting is enabled using `eslint.autoFixOnSave`. Notice that the setting is only honored when `autoSave` is not set to `after delay`.
### Set up
- install the latest version of the vscode-eslint extension (version 1.0.8)
- create a new workspace with eslint install (npm install eslint). Also create a .eslintrc file

``` json
{
    "env": {
        "commonjs": true,
        "es6": true,
        "node": true
    },
    "rules": {
        "no-const-assign": "warn",
        "no-this-before-super": "warn",
        "no-undef": "warn",
        "no-unreachable": "warn",
        "no-unused-vars": "warn",
        "constructor-super": "warn",
        "valid-typeof": "warn",
        "no-extra-semi": "warn"
    }
}
```
- file issues here: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-eslint
### Test
- ensure that you have auto save after delay disabled
- ensure that you have format on save disabled.
- create a JS file and add an extra semicolon. It should be removed on save. 
- test other ESLint warnings that offer a auto fix. See rules with a wrench here: http://eslint.org/docs/rules/. Please note that some rules need an n pass fix approach which is currently not implemented yet. So only test one rule at a time.

data.title: Missing keyboard shortcut features from Atom

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I created an [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.atom-keybindings) to port Atom keybindings to VS Code keybindings. I made a list of all the keybindings that were missing analogous commands in VS Code. 

Below is the list roughly ordered by importance. Please comment if I missed one. If an extension exists with the functionality, I added it in the far right column. 

| Windows, Linux | Mac | Description | Issue | Extension |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| ctrl+j, ctrl+j | cmd+j | Join current line and next line | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1759 | [Join Lines](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wmaurer.join-lines) |
| ctrl+shift+v | cmd+shift+v | Paste and indent | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/6392 | [Paste and Indent](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Rubymaniac.vscode-paste-and-indent) |
| ctrl+t | ctrl+t | Transpose | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8574 | [transpose](*https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=v4run.transpose) |
| ctrl++ | cmd++ and cmd+= | Increase Font Size | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14031 | [FontSize Shortcuts](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=peterjuras.fontsize-shortcuts) |
| ctrl+- | cmd+- | Decrease Font Size | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14031 | [FontSize Shortcuts](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=peterjuras.fontsize-shortcuts) |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>u</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>u</kbd> | Upper case | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14096 | [change case](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wmaurer.change-case) |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>l</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>l</kbd> | Lower case | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14096 | [change case](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=wmaurer.change-case) |
| ctrl+k ctrl+6 | cmd+k cmd+6 | Fold level 6 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |
| ctrl+k ctrl+7 | cmd+k cmd+7 | Fold level 7 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |
| ctrl+k ctrl+8 | cmd+k cmd+8 | Fold level 8 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |
| ctrl+k ctrl+9 | cmd+k cmd+9 | Fold level 9 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |

data.title: Test: TypeScript upgrade to 2.0.6
data.body:
The tsserver we ship out of the box with VS Code got upgraded to 2.0.6. Since 2.0.6 has API changes the code talking to the tsserver is now version aware. We therefore need to sanity check the TS features against a 1.8.10, a 2.0.3 and the shipped 2.0.6 version.
- [x] 1.8.10 -  @mousetraps
- [x] 2.0.3 -  @roblourens 
- [x] 2.0.6 - @egamma 

Complexity: 4
## Feature testing
- create a new workspace. If you test 1.8.10 or 2.0.3 install typescript into the workspace using npm install typescript@x.x.x and use the `typescript.tsdk` to point to the local tsserver directory.
- test all TS functions like: error reporting, intellisense, goto definition, find references, format, format on type, hover, rename, document symbols and workspace symbols.
- try things...
- if you test the 2.0.6 version also test the following scenario: create a new workspace with two js files but no tsconfig.json or jsconfig.json. The two JS file should reference globals symbols from the other file but should not refer to the other file using /// reference statements or import statements. Open both files and trigger workspace symbols. Ensure that you see the symbols from both files. Also test find references on a symbol that is referenced in the other file
- if the error is an 'obvious' TypeScript problem file the issue directly against the TS repository: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript. Otherwise file it against vscode.

data.title: ctrl+alt+p no longer works as a keybinding when the editor is focused
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.7.0-insider (c038219f8d137b4972a15346b81ea03751d669d4, 2016-10-24T10:03:46.015Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-45-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run `code-insiders --disable-extensions`
2. Add keybinding: `{ "key": "ctrl+alt+p",    "command": "workbench.action.closeAllEditors" },`
3. Focus an editor and use it, nothing happens

I saw this when trying to use https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=felipecaputo.git-project-manager, it's a regression in the last 1-3 days I would guess.

data.title: Return focus to terminal after toggling Sidebar
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open terminal and focus it.
2. `Cmd+B` two times.
3. Focus is on editor. Should be on terminal I think.
